newsitem.title: GERMANY: Fed must be preemptive against inflation -- Parry.
newsitem.headline: Fed must be preemptive against inflation -- Parry.

text.p: President of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco Robert Parry said it is "absolutely essential" the central bank be forward looking in its fight against inflation.
Parry, speaking to reporters here, said he was "surprised" that inflation has not yet shown up in the U.S. economy as it would be expected under conventional economic models.

"The Fed always has to be forward looking and cannot wait until problems surface. It can take six months to two years for inflation to show up so I think it's absolutely essential for the Fed to be forward looking," Parry said.

Parry said he believes U.S. inflation is in a modest upward trend, adding that he was more concerned about the Consumer Price Index (CPI) being above financial market forecasts rather than below them.
"I think the indications are on the uppick. I'm more concerned about inflation being above the (financial markets') forecast than below the forecast," Parry said.
He also said he sees few signs of wage pressures in U.S. labor markets, adding that he was watching excess capacity in the economy as a potential inflation source.
Parry said regional upward pressure on wages was particularly seen in the northwest part of the U.S. and in the Silicon Valley in California.
"I think there are few overall signs of wage inflation," Parry said.
"My concern is the result of the fact that there appears to be a little excess capacity. I don't see the inflation signs, but I see the factors that precede an increase in inflation," he added.
He was referring to the current low unemployment rate and high capacity utilization of the U.S. economy. "Those factors would lead one to be cautious," he added.
Parry also said he expects first quarter Gross Domestic Product growth to be around 3.0 percent and a little under 2.5 percent for all of 1997.
"If I had to pick a round number (for Q1 GDP), it would be a three (percent) ... I would expect growth of a little less than 2.5 percent for the year," he said.
He also said the real federal funds rate is currently "not too wide off the mark."
